general.headline: HR Business Partner
general.description:
A highly capable and commercially astute HR Professional; I have experience working within large scale national and multi-national organisations encompassing Corporate, Retail, Manufacturing and Sales environments.

Tertiary qualified and with 9+ years of HR generalist experience, I started my career in 2008 working as the Organisational Development Coordinator for Kmart during the Wesfarmers acquisition of Coles Group.  At that early stage Kmart was regarded as the 'ugly duckling' of the Group and it was so rewarding contributing to the brand's transformation into one of Australia's most successful retailers. From Kmart I moved to Country Road in 2012, another household name in Australian retail, where my focus was on providing HR support for retail stores. During my tenure I was fortunate to be a part of Country Road's acquisition and integration of the Witchery & Mimco brands. 

Excited to experience a new and challenging industry I joined Aspen Pharma in 2013 as their HR Advisor. Aspen had acquired Sigma in 2011 resulting in the organisation expanding from a team of 60 to 950 staff. I was charged with establishing a variety of HR processes and policies to support the rapidly growing business. In 2015 I was promoted to HR Business Partner where I continue to offer specialist HR/IR/ER support. 

Key Specialisms & Strengths
•	Employee Relations knowledge & application
•	Training & Facilitation 	
•	Industrial Relations / Union Negotiations 	
•	HR Strategy & Planning
•	Relationship Building & Influencing
•	Performance Coaching & Counselling 	
•	Industrial/Employment Tribunal Advocacy
•	Change Management 	
•	Workplace Investigations
•	Restructures & Redundancies	
•	Recruitment

jobs.description:
Promoted to the position of HR Business Partner in recognition of the high level of support and influence provided, I continue to work closely with the management team identifying ways to improve productivity, build leadership capability, attract and develop talent, and drive compliance to reduce risk.

Recent achievements include the introduction of a human error reduction program, overhauling Aspen's recruitment procedures to improve the quality of candidates hired, and driving cultural change around mental health & wellbeing. 

As the lead negotiator for Aspen during a long running campaign with two unions, resulting in industrial action and appearances at the Fair Work Commission, we were successful in achieving EBA outcomes favourable to Aspen such as a 30% reduction in the cost of casual labour and further improvements to RDO rosters enhancing flexibility and production uptime. A key focus of mine during this challenging period was to encourage respectful conduct between the parties in the interests of maintaining healthy workplace relationships post-negotiations.

Brought in to provide dedicated HR/IR/ER support to the manufacturing operations
      group (approx. 350+ white & blue collar employees), my responsibility also extended
      to generalist HR support for the rest of the Aspen business (including national sales,
      
      marketing and support functions).

... See more

As a first point of contact, my role was to provide generalist HR/ER advice for Regional Managers and over 600 managers and employees across NSW/ACT. To educate and coach store management teams on proper workplace conduct relating to company policy, terminations/dismissals, performance management and EBA interpretation. To lead investigations relating to theft, bullying, harassment and breaches of policy. To improve manager bench strength within the state by recruiting top talent and developing line manager capability.

Returning to Kmart after a 12 month travel break, my role was to effectively coordinate generalist HR activities for over 800 National Office staff. 
Key deliverables include: providing timely and accurate advice to Line Managers; succession planning; performance management; managing ill/injured employees and the return to work process; end-to-end recruitment for selected roles; and assisting with restructures and redundancies.

As the Organisational Development Coordinator/HR Coordinator, my role was to coordinate all OD initiatives for the business including the roll out of a new culture change program and performance review process. At all times I ensured that OD programs supported and aligned with Kmart's strategy, whilst driving a positive and high performing culture. I consistently provided support to and communicated with all key stakeholders including the Executive team, Line Managers and HR Managers. Additional major projects included a revised reward and recognition program, new EAP program, and the implementation of a new succession planning process.

During my final year at University, I undertook work placement at National Foods in the HR department. Over two months I had the opportunity to assist with generalist HR duties, conduct a succession planning interview analysis, complete a cost/benefit analysis of temporary staff, and carry out a number of administrative duties such as updating employee training records, organisational structure and reporting schedules.

schools.description: In a global economy characterised by customisation, speed and innovation, effective human resource management (HRM) is key to successful strategy execution. Your organisation’s core assets are your employees: their knowledge, skills and relationships. Human and social capital might be less tangible than financial or physical assets, but are no less critical to organisational success.Through Strategic HR Leadership, you will understand the strategic role HRM plays in providing your organisation with a sustained, competitive advantage by unlocking your employees’ productive potential. You will also identify and develop the leadership behaviours you need to ensure your organisation attracts and retains quality people for the long term.

Graduating from The University of Sydney in 1989, and admitted as a solicitor of the Supreme Court and High Court of Australia, Cynthia Bluett has over 25 years' experience working at top tier Sydney and London law firms in family law, commercial law and insurance litigation. Cynthia is involved in the resolution of matters concerning complex financial structures and high net worth assets.

Doyle's Guide recognised Cynthia as a recommended family lawyer for parenting and children’s matters in the New South Wales legal market for 2018.

Cynthia joined the firm in October 2004 and since then has worked solely in family law and represents in all aspects of family law and advises clients on adoption, Financial Agreements, de facto including same sex relationships, parenting matters, financial and property settlements. 

 Cynthia is a family law specialist accredited by the Law Society of New South Wales and works with Relationships Australia in their interdisciplinary collaborative family law program. She applies her experience and practical approach to the early resolution of both collaborative and litigated cases.

 Cynthia is a member of:
•Training & Standards Committee, Australian Association Collaborative Professionals
•International Academy of Collaborative Professionals
•Collaborative Professionals (NSW) Inc
•Central Sydney Collaborative Forum
•The Law Society of New South Wales

general.headline: Partner, Pearson Emerson Meyer Family Lawyers
general.description:
Max Meyer was one of the first lawyers accredited as a Family Law Specialist in New South Wales.

He was admitted to practice in 1971. He was the partner in charge of the Family Law Group at Marshall Marks Kennedy for 11 years. He then founded the firm of Meyer Pigdon, then later Meyer Partners Family Lawyers. He is now a Partner of Pearson Emerson Meyer Family Lawyers.

Max is a member of the New South Wales Law Society and the Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia. He was one of the first two lawyers practising in New South Wales to have been elected as a Fellow of the elite International Academy of Family Lawyers. Max is the first elected President of the newly formed Asia Pacific Chapter of the International Academy of Family Lawyers and has been appointed to the IAFL Nominating Committee.

He was the only Australian lawyer to be invited to contribute the chapter on Australian family law to "Family Law Jurisdictional Comparisons" published by Thomson Reuters in 2011, an industry internationally recognised and distributed book on international family law. He has now revised this for the 2nd, 3rd and 4th editions. More recently, Max has been invited to contribute the chapter on Australian family law to the third edition of “Family Law and Practice in Hong Kong” published by Sweet & Maxwell. Max has also been invited to contribute towards the Australian Chapter within the 2019 edition of “The International Comparative Legal Guide to Family Law.  He often speaks on family law issues including at international conferences.

He has acted in major cases including international financial disputes on marital breakdown, and other disputes for high profile and high net worth professional and business clients. A number of his cases have established legal precedent.

general.headline: Director, Watts McCray Lawyers. Accredited Specialist- Family Law. Private Practice Lawyer of the Year, Women Lawyers Association of NSW Awards, 2017.
general.company: Watts McCray Family and Divorce Lawyers
general.school: Graduate Diploma of Legal Practice- College of Law
general.description:
Kate was admitted in 2006, commencing her legal career in Community Legal Centres before moving to private practice in 2007 where she has worked exclusively in family law.  Kate became an Accredited Specialist in Family Law in 2011 and a Senior Associate the same year. Kate became a Partner in July 2016 and was awarded the ‘Private Practice Lawyer of the Year Award’ through the NSW Women Lawyer’s Association. Kate has recently been nominated for ‘Partner of the Year’ through the Lawyer’s Weekly- Women in Law Awards. 

Kate currently leads the family law team at Watts McCray's Central Coast office in Erina, NSW. Kate also practises from the Parramatta and Sydney offices of Watts McCray. 

As an Accredited Specialist in Family Law, Kate is comfortable with complex and high wealth family law matters, including those with an international component. Kate is skilled at drafting legal documents including Binding Financial Agreements, Child Support Agreements and other Court documents and she regularly appears as a Court advocate in Sydney, Parramatta and Newcastle. 

Kate fully appreciates the high stress that can potentially accompany family law matters and so ensures where possible that the advice and information she provides to you is delivered in plain English to minimise confusion and further distress and to simplify the complicated legal process. Kate completed a combined Bachelor of Communications (Journalism) and Bachelor of Laws at the University of Western Sydney and her Graduate Diploma of Legal Practice at the College of Law. Kate has experience in writing and presenting CLE papers on family law issues, allowing her to diversify the way in which she applies her legal knowledge, increasing her understanding of the law through communication, benefiting you when it comes to a Court room situation or negotiation.

general.headline: Technology Lawyer at Telstra
general.description:
Shane is currently a commercial / technology lawyer within the legal team at Telstra.  At Telstra Shane advises on large scale pro-active and responsive tenders and commercial enterprise transactions. His portfolio also includes advising on technology supply agreements, data protection, privacy, and the emerging area of the Internet of Things (IoT), including advising on retail marketing and media Smart Home devices. 
Shane is also a member of the Telstra Legal Innovation Forum (LIF), which adopts design thinking to challenge the status quo and create innovative technology and process solutions. The LIF has been the subject of a case study by Harvard Law School.  

Prior to this he was Legal Counsel for Adecco Group Australia & New Zealand, advising across all companies within the group including Modis (formally Ajilon), Judd Farris, Pontoon, Adecco, and Lee Hecht Harrison. Within this role he provided broad commercial legal advice including contract drafting & negotiation, employment law, superannuation, IT, and IP.

Shane started his legal career at Corrs Chambers Westgarth. At Corrs, he acted in a variety of large commercial transactions and disputes and completed a secondment to the Department of Environment & Primary Industries. Shane combined his practical business experience and industry knowledge to deliver commercial results.

Shane holds a Bachelor of Laws degree from Bond University, graduating with Honours. Shane was awarded ‘first in class’ from the Dean of the law school for achieving the highest mark in the subject of Australian Government and Politics. He was also selected as ambassador of the Law School for three consecutive years.

Prior to practicing law Shane specialised in the field of corporate learning and development, with a focus on the design, and implementation of organisational development projects and facilitation. This experience enables Shane to present often complex legal topics in an engaging way to any audience.

general.headline: Boss at Matcha Mylkbar
general.description:
The Monash Law graduate fell in love with all things hospitality and hasn’t turned back since.

Since graduating law, Mark has owned and operated eleven hospitality venues currently operating five venues and employing over 120 staff.

Mark Filippelli has solidified his position on the wholesome cafe scene. His current list of operations includes Matcha Mylkbar, il Fornaio, The Last Piece, South Society and Feast of Merit.

Mark is a pioneer and advocate for community supported agriculture with the aim to give consumers no choice but to join the global movement towards, low impact, high nutritious, but most importantly fun food choices. His ethos is simple and understated, he takes pride in sourcing produce from local suppliers who under their environmental impact and allows his chefs to have fun with the goods nature provides.

Mark is also strongly involved with YGAP and over the last two years has volunteered as project leader, business advisor and managing director for the organisations social enterprise restaurant, Feast of Merit. Mark is so happy to have found YGAP, “it has had such a powerful impact on my life - it is incredible to know that by taking a commercial approach to a social problem and through our everyday choices we can actually make a difference.

With plans to open operations in Sydney next year, Mark has also set his sights on expansion overseas with plans for operations in LA and NYC in 2017. Watch this space.

jobs.description:
Matcha Mylkbar is Australia's first specialty matcha cafe showcasing this vibrant green superfood as well as a world leading, innovative plant-based breakfast and lunch menu. There are five "Blue Zones" in the world where people live longer than anywhere else and the primary factor they share in common is a majority plant-based diet - not because of any moral/ethical/political concerns but simply due to what is sustainable. Okinawa, Japan is one of the five zones and has the highest number of centenarians in the world, largely due to a plant-based diet and high levels of matcha consumption. Matcha Mylkbar's menu is built around this research and a philosophy of putting the sustainability and longevity benefits of plant based eating at the Melbourne cafe culture's disposal in a way that takes the moral/political/ethical elements and stigma away from vegan dining. 

Each dish is designed to please all palates, preferences and dietary requirements. We have even developed a "vegan egg" made wholly of plant based materials but with the same consistency and texture of a regular egg. This is culinary innovation as you've never seen it before! The beverages are equally as progressive featuring Melbourne's first beetroot and mushroom lattes and, of course, a host of matcha themed drinks. The menu can be found online at www.matchamylkbar.com and press features include:

Vogue (US and AUS)
Grazia (France)
The Age
The Weekly Review
Broadsheet
Collective Hub
Urban List Melbourne
Concrete Playground
Sporteluxe
Good Food AU
Tully Lou
Couturing

and the list continues to grow.

Social Enterprise Restaurant owned by YGAP

Philosophy

In Nagaland, far northeast of India, people believe that wealth should be celebrated and shared.  When a member of the Naga community comes into wealth they host a feast for the whole village. Everyone in the community is invited to join the feast which continues until the host has shared their wealth.  The feasting and festival can last for several weeks, including poor and underprivileged people to celebrate the sharing of wealth and the joy it brings.

When the feast is finished and the community celebrated, the host resumes life once more – with just the cloak on their shoulders. This cloak signifies the highest social prestige one can achieve in Nagaland: hosting a Feast of Merit.

Melbourne’s Feast of Merit honours this Naga tradition, with 100 percent of its profits directly supporting YGAP’s movement of impact entrepreneurs who are improving the lives of people living in poverty.

http://www.feastofmerit.com/

general.headline: Co-founder, Managing Director at Thankyou
general.description:
In 2008, I led a group of university students in the establishment of a social enterprise called Thankyou Water. Our aim was to launch a bottled water product that would exist for the sole purpose of funding water projects in developing nations.

It was a tough startup journey and we encountered a lot of setbacks along the way. We were a group of young people with limited business experience but we had loads of determination and that was what drove us to continue building the business, even through the tough times. 

In July 2013, after already having secured major deals with 7-Eleven Australia and Australia Post for our bottled water, we rebranded to Thankyou and launched two new ranges - Thankyou food and Thankyou body care. The reason behind this was to enable us to fund food and health and hygiene projects in developing nations as well as water projects. We also launched a bold campaign that resulted in Coles and Woolworths agreeing to stock our entire range of products, which catapulted our business into a season of strong growth, which meant our impact through our projects grew exponentially. 

In February 2016, we launched our boldest move yet - Chapter One. A pay-what-you-want book of which 100% of the profits would fund the future of Thankyou. To date, thanks to the incredible support of the Australian public, we've raised over $1.4 million from sales of Chapter One. These funds will allow us to launch our baby range in late 2016 which will fund child and maternal health programs around the globe and our first international market in 2017, New Zealand. 

We're excited that we've been able to help thousands of people gain access to water, food, hygiene and sanitation training and maternal and child health programs. Our aim is to keep growing so we can continue to impact many more lives in need, because we believe that together we can help end global poverty.

jobs.description:
My role as Managing Director involves driving the growth of Thankyou and overseeing

    My ultimate goal is to see Thankyou become a household name in Australia so we can
      go from helping thousands of people with water, food and health and hygiene training,
      
      to one day helping millions of people in need.

general.headline: Strategy & Analytics Director at Carlton & United Breweries
general.description:
I lead CUB’s Strategy, Analytics and Projects team, with responsibility for our long-term strategy, delivering value through advanced analytics and leading our largest, highest-value transformation projects.

Energetic, hardworking and compassionate, I’m an experienced M&A and business strategist with a deep passion for people, CUB and - of course - the beer industry. As Strategy & Analytics Director for Carlton & United Breweries, I relish the opportunity to lead high-impact and diverse projects across the entire business and influence our long-term strategic vision. I’m now also beginning the exciting journey of setting up a new team to take analytics and data-driven decision-making within CUB to the next level.

My career at CUB began in the Legal team as an M&A lawyer, but over my years with the company I’ve gained expertise across a wide range of functions having led large strategic projects spanning areas such as M&A, Integration, Logistics, Category Development, Portfolio Strategy, Joint Ventures and Manufacturing. 

I love working with teams across all functions and levels of our business and getting into the detail of what makes our company tick. This came to life most recently when I led the integration of two craft breweries (4 Pines Brewing Co. and Pirate Life Brewing) into the broader CUB and AB InBev business. 
 
Beer is a community product, and I’m very proud and passionate about CUB’s rich history in Australia and the positive impact our products can have on our community. CUB has offered me amazing opportunities and the chance to grow, and I hope to continue to offer similar opportunities to others and to build teams filled with diverse, talented and ambitious individuals who are united by their equal passion for our business, brands and people.

general.company: Victorian Society for Computers and the Law
general.description:
James joined King & Wood Mallesons in September 2016 and is a TMET (technology, media, entertainment and telecommunications) Senior Associate in the Mergers and Acquisitions group. He graduated from Monash University with a combined Bachelor of Laws (with Honours) and Bachelor of Commerce (with a Dean's Commendation) in 2012.  He was admitted as an Australian Lawyer in December 2013.

James advises public and private clients and internal business stakeholders on a range of general technology, corporate, intellectual property, and regulatory matters, and assists in drafting documents for, and negotiating, various corporate and technology transactions.  James has been involved in advising on and drafting documentation for, large IT outsourcing projects and has experience drafting and negotiating Agile software and solution development agreements. James also advises on cloud computing, software licensing and privacy and data protection issues.

Some of the key matters James has worked on are as follows:

- Drafting a suit of standard IT development contracts including modules for differing service types.
- Advising on complex contractual interpretation issues on large multi-jurisdictional telecommunications agreements.
- Drafting and negotiating a number of agile development agreements adopting hybrid approaches designed to apportion risk between the contracting parties whilst retaining flexibility.
- Requests for tender issued by large government departments and corporate entities including drafting and negotiating contractual positions. 
- Drafted documentation for and negotiated issues relating to, large IT outsourcing arrangements requiring integration with existing systems provided by multiple suppliers.
- Assisted client with sponsorship of a major AFL club.

Freeplay champions diversity and inclusion and is particulary involved in creating a safe space for gamers and developers from across society to attend and enjoy what games offer.

general.headline: Reader at Victorian Bar
general.description:
Emma is completing the Bar Readers' Course at the Victorian Bar. 

Most recently she was Executive Officer at the Supreme Court of Victoria and previously was associate to the Honourable Justice Elliott in the Trial Division of the Court. 

Prior to this Emma worked for the Director General of the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) in Geneva, Switzerland. She was admitted to legal practice at the Supreme Court of Victoria in March 2013.

Emma's qualifications include: a Bachelor of Civil Law (BCL) from Oxford University, a JD from Melbourne Law School (including prizes in Property, Dispute Resolution and Legal Research) and a BA Hons in English Language and Literature, also from Oxford.

Before retraining in law Emma was an actress in the UK, US and Australia working for the Royal Shakespeare Company, Royal National Theatre and Disney amongst others. She also developed, performed and produced one-woman shows. While 'resting' between acting jobs she worked in research and project management positions predominately in the not-for-profit sector.

Research included: legal, political, philosophical, economic, cultural and social perspectives on a range of subjects including private and public international law, technology law and policy, intellectual property law and policy in multiple jurisdictions and current events. 

The role also included coordinating contributions from WIPO colleagues and external experts into the Director General’s speeches and publications and assisting various teams with specific projects as directed.

Provided legal research and analysis on topics including: sentencing practices and the rules of procedure at international tribunals (specifically those rules relating to hearsay and subpoenas) and the scope of self-defence under public international law. jobs.description:
Criminal defence lawyer and I appear in the Magistrates Court regularly in summary
      
      matters and indictable matters that are tried summarily

I work in a suburban general practice practising in criminal law, commercial, family, civil litigation, wills & estate, and migration law. 

I appeared regularly in the Magistrates Court for summary offences  and minor civil claims not limited to breach of contract, motor vehicle accident claims & debt claim. 

I appeared regularly in the federal circuit court and federal court of Australia in relation to divorce applications, custody disputes & property matters. 

I also advised small investors and businesses especially our business migration clients who must acquire businesses in South Australia.

Work in the Humanitarian team undertaking work in crime, small civil claims, civil
      
      litigation & migration (onshore & offshore)

Work in the Intellectual Property/IT Regulatory Team. I undertook both transactional and litigation work including preparing letters of advice, memos, briefs, affidavits, witness statements and franchise agreements. 

Prepared and provided legal advice in the environmental and planning space.

Also worked in the Disputes Team

Drafted commercial deeds between the Government of South Australia and independent parties

Assisted in drafting and preparing commercial sound advice with the assistance and supervision of Crown solicitors.

In this role, I am able to give back to my community and provide interpretive services through the legal service commission, the courts and administrative tribunals. 

I have participated in a 7 days criminal trial of an indictable offence in this role, allowing me to observe court practices including court etiquette, advocacy in action such from the prosecution opening their cases, appointment of the jury, calling of witnesses both lay and expert witnesses, examination in chief, cross examination and final addresses by both defence and prosecution counsel. 

I also provide interpreting services to the legal service commission in areas of family law, criminal and minor civil claims.

Conducted legal research and assisted in drafting submissions for the Solicitor-General on appeal matters to the Supreme Court of South Australia and the High Court of Australia. 

Conducted legal research and drafted opinions for the Solicitor General advising the Attorney-General on administrative and constitutional matters as well as criminal law reforms.

Assisted in preparing for and attended an appeal to the High Court for Judicial Review regarding a decision of the Federal Court affirming the decision of the Refugee Review Tribunal by putting together index brief and a brief for counsel.

Drafted consent orders regarding property settlements, custody of children, and shared parental responsibility regarding children living arrangements; drafted letters to clients, binding financial agreement between parties, wills, probates and submission opposing subpoenaed documents.

Drafted legal documents including subpoenas, affidavits, counsel briefs, letters to counter parties on conveyancing matters, lodge and file legal documents including caveats, requisitions, subpoenas.

Attended and assisted counsel in criminal trials, appeared before the Magistrate on leave and successfully obtained orders for adjournments and subpoenas.

Drafted legal documents and provided general legal advice in areas such as fencing disputes, small debt claims, intellectual property, and family law.

Conducted file management, conflict checks using a legal software (LEAP) employed by the clinic. 

Attended and conducted interviews under the supervision and guidance of clinic supervisors.

Conducted research, conflict checks and file management.
      

    
      

    Attended interviews between counsel and clients as an observer then later discussed
      
      my observations with counsel and my thoughts on the matter.

I work collaboratively with senior financial advisors and junior associates in providing

general.headline: Senior Associate to The Honourable Justice Peter Kidd, Chief Judge of the County Court at County Court of Victoria.
general.description:
Bridie is currently Senior Associate to The Honourable Justice Peter Kidd, Chief Judge of the County Court of Victoria. Bridie has been in this role since June 2017. 

Immediately prior to this, Bridie was Senior Associate to The Honourable Justice Stephen Kaye AM, of the Supreme Court of Victoria (June 2016 – June 2017).  During this time, his Honour sat in both the Court of Appeal and Criminal Trial Division. Bridie undertook legal and administrative work both in Court and in Chambers, including clerking, legal research and judgment proofing. 

Bridie’s first role, post admission was as a solicitor advocate for a criminal defence law firm. Bridie practised as a solicitor advocate for two and half years at Patrick W. Dwyer (December 2013 – June 2016). Bridie appeared on a daily basis in the Magistrates’ Court of Victoria and in routine County Court matters. Bridie had conduct of serious indictable matters and prepared and instructed junior and senior counsel across all jurisdictions.

Bridie was admitted as a Barrister and Solicitor of the Supreme Court of Victoria in December 2013. Bridie graduated from Monash University in 2013 with a Bachelor of Laws (First Class Honours) and a Bachelor of Arts.

I have a general commercial and common law practice at the Bar, accepting briefs to appear and advise in commercial, equity, trusts and probate matters.  This encompasses applications under the Trustee Act 1958, the Wills Act 1997 and the Administration and Probate Act 1958, including testators family maintenance.

Prior to coming to the Bar, I was the senior associate to the Honourable Justice McMillan at the Supreme Court of Victoria.  I assisted her Honour in the running of the Trusts, Equity and Probate List and the Testators Family Maintenance List in the Common Law Division, routinely sitting in complex probate and trusts proceedings and trials in a range of areas, including equity, property, judicial review and commercial law.  I also supported her Honour on urgent probate applications, including limited grants ad colligendum bona, ad litem and pendente lite.

My work involved assisting clients with trademark registrations and disputes, mergers and acquisitions and the drafting of complex contracts in the IT and media industries.

I have specific experience in large scale regulatory investigations and associated high profile, complex litigation, tax and commercial disputes involving ASX listed and multinational companies. I also have advisory experience in compliance and risk management in the mining, financial services and retail sectors.
